channel.title: Build a computer with $500 or less
channel.description:
Ok, using newegg.com and tigerdirect.com, what is the best computer you can build with $500 or less?
Ideally, all of the parts should come from newegg and should have at least 4 eggs, but we'll see what you guys come up with.
It should have a cd/dvd drive, a respectable hdd, a gfx card, mobo, c2d or similar, etc.

item.title: Build a computer with $500 or less
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“VB7 Rocks, post:27, topic:161539”]I’m a huge fan of SATA, it’s got small connectors (little less than width of my thumbnail), and it looks a lot better in the case than an IDE ribbon cable. I don’t know if PATA uses the same gray ribbon cable as IDE, but SATA is much easier to wire around in the case as it’s much smaller.

I use SATA for both HDD’s and optical drives on my main rig, but I’ve got another that has a SATA setup on the HDD’s but IDE for the opticals. It works out okay, but the IDE ribbon is stuffed into the extra space where the empty drive bays are, and it doesn’t look too pleasing.

I don’t really see a speed difference in optical drives for IDE vs SATA, but for HDD’s, SATA is definitely faster for me.[/quote]

Chose to go with an IDE DVD burner instead of simply a combo drive. I’d like the ability to burn DVD’s, though I don’t see why I’d need them. PATA is more or less equal to IDE.

EDIT: Changed my mind again. SATA it is.

EDIT: Come on, guys. I need your thoughts on this.

https://secure.newegg.com/NewVersion/WishList/PublicWishDetail.asp?WishListNumber=7786888

Read full topic
item.source: Build a computer with $500 or less

item.title: Build a computer with $500 or less
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

xxlegitxx:

Also, nothing else will be using the PATA cable, so I might as well save a dollar, and buy a PATA combo drive as opposed to a SATA drive, right? SATA vs. IDE/PATA

I’m a huge fan of SATA, it’s got small connectors (little less than width of my thumbnail), and it looks a lot better in the case than an IDE ribbon cable. I don’t know if PATA uses the same gray ribbon cable as IDE, but SATA is much easier to wire around in the case as it’s much smaller.

I use SATA for both HDD’s and optical drives on my main rig, but I’ve got another that has a SATA setup on the HDD’s but IDE for the opticals. It works out okay, but the IDE ribbon is stuffed into the extra space where the empty drive bays are, and it doesn’t look too pleasing.

I don’t really see a speed difference in optical drives for IDE vs SATA, but for HDD’s, SATA is definitely faster for me.

Read full topic
item.source: Build a computer with $500 or less

item.title: Build a computer with $500 or less
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

VB7 Rocks:

Not to mention his rig is missing a power supply, lel.

Yea lol, I noticed it when I was putting a master list for myself, taking hints from their lists and Toms Hardware.

I think I’ll go MicroATX; I doubt I’ll be OC-ing.

EDIT: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16856167009

Too cheap?

And MSI MicroATX Mobo vs. ASRock MicroATX Mobo… I think the second is better. $25 cheaper, still has 5 stars, 1000MHz HT as opposed to 800MHz HT, 6 usb vs. 4, wtf… no southbridge? is it necessary?, reports problems of psu cord running across cpu though I can deal with that, no gigabit lan, no firewire, no dvi. However, would a 20+4 pin psu work with a 20 pin mobo?

Here’s my finished PC: https://secure.newegg.com/NewVersion/WishList/PublicWishDetail.asp?WishListNumber=7786888
$492.92 - Mail-in rebates + Shipping.
I chose the CPU specifically so it could handle the full 800 MHz RAM speed. The case is really nice, from the reviews. The mobo is dirt cheap yet reliable… the main problems were listed above. The GFX card doesn’t have a fan; the case has an extra intake fan to make up for it, and I really don’t game all that often. PSU I might bump up to a Silverstone, because Toms Hardware strongly recommended it. Judging by the facts and reviews… I think it would be worth it. RAM is basically the best I could get. HDD is good enough for me. DVD burner is fine. Do you see any compatibility issues? Am I using too many SATA components? What the hell do I do for a southbridge, and why is there none?

Read full topic
item.source: Build a computer with $500 or less

item.title: Build a computer with $500 or less
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

[quote=“FastBawlz, post:20, topic:161539”][quote author=RXVL link=topic=219845.msg1907193#msg1907193 date=1196485889]
Here you go ;):

http://secure.newegg.com/NewVersion/wishlist/PublicWishDetail.asp?WishListNumber=7771368

After the mail in rebates I think I went something like $15 over, but that’s a smokin’ rig right there. The RAM is super cheap and you have a great mobo, so if you want 4GB’s of RAM at the cheapest prices it will be at until literally 3 years later, I suggest you get it now, 2GB’s of Corsair XMS RAM for $38 is the best deal ever, I’m buying 4 sets for my home server (not ruinscape).
[/quote]

Eww 8600GT.
You can get RAM that good for $44 that are just as good.[/quote]

Not to mention his rig is missing a power supply, lel.

Read full topic
item.source: Build a computer with $500 or less

item.title: Build a computer with $500 or less
item.dc:creator: @RXVL RXVL
item.description:
@RXVL wrote:

Dell is shit, it’s a fact. They bundle computers with useless software and fuck up your Windows install. Their products are overpriced and underpowered, and most of their cases are pieces of shit. Dells are meant to break within 3 years of purchasing one. So don’t talk about something you don’t know.

Read full topic
item.source: Build a computer with $500 or less

item.title: Build a computer with $500 or less
item.dc:creator: @daycrawler daycrawler
item.description:
@daycrawler wrote:

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:12, topic:161539”][quote author=sidishere link=topic=219845.msg1906257#msg1906257 date=1196415201]
i really dont think that you could build a great computer with 500 bucks maybe around 700-800 you could get a decent one.
[/quote]

I can get a decent computer with $500. My computer is Celeron D with 768mb and it’s considered decent. And I suppose it’s worth <$100 nowadays.

I hope you don’t mean from a manufacturer, as a $700 laptop would be shit (~500 MB RAM, if I’m not mistaken).

You can get laptop for $660, then add this ram: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820231116

you guys may know dell sucks, but its cheap

Those harddrives will fail in a year, and the screen will fall apart, the keys will be missing, the touchpad won’t work. Dells are a mess, they really are.[/quote]
Funny considering I’m running a dell desktop for four years now and it’s works great. My sister has a laptop from dell and had it for six years and it just recently died. So don’t bad mouth dell.

Read full topic
item.source: Build a computer with $500 or less

item.title: Build a computer with $500 or less
item.dc:creator: @RXVL RXVL
item.description:
@RXVL wrote:

And it’s Corsair RAM, not that piece of shit no-name RAM that your thinking of. Corsair hands down beat OCZ, GSkill, Patriot, and all the other big RAM company’s in all the tests that every magazine ran.
